title: Fix usage of actual/expected in #assertEquals
body: This is a fix for javadoc in Stopwatch and tests which is using wrong order of actual/expected in #assertEquals.

title: Implementation for Issue #45
body:
* Add a new annotation named `ParameterRule`.
* Add a new protected inner class that extends
`TestClassRunnerForParameters` named `SingleInstanceRunnerForParameters`.
* Instantiates TestClassRunnerForParameters or
SingleInstanceRunnerForParameters depending if ParameterRule exists or
not.
* Modified `BlockJUnit4ClassRunner` by converting some methods from
private to protected.

title: Improvement: Concurrent Queue in RunNotifier instead of Old Synchronized ArrayList
body:
The old RunNotifier uses synchronized ArrayList in Listeners.

Without the synchronization the concurrently modified Listeners throw ConcurrentModificationException on iterator.

This synchronization is no longer needed with ConcurrentLinkedQueue because it is already thread safe and non-blocking.

This change will speed up tests because of not having any locks.

title: Updated README to have similar contents as README.html
body:
Updated README so that all users visiting project page would get information about the project.

This would also be useful for [Issue 562](https://github.com/KentBeck/junit/issues/562)

body:
Added a README.md file so that project information would be shown on home page of repo.

This would also be useful for [Issue#562](https://github.com/KentBeck/junit/issues/562)

title: Created README.md
body:
Created a new README.md file with links to WiKi and getting started guide.
Deleted README.html and README files as the information in those file was out of date.

For more information, please check [Original pull request](https://github.com/KentBeck/junit/pull/580) and [Issue 562](https://github.com/KentBeck/junit/issues/562)

title: RuleChain.of(...)
body:
The existing way of constructing RuleChain using outerRule() and around() calls seems too verbose without any additional benefits.
I would like to have simpler way of constructing a chain. From my point of view the most logical way is  passing them all as parameters of the single method call.

title: ExpectedException doesn't fail when an AssertionError is expected but not thrown
body:
When a tests expects code under test to throw an AssertionError by using ExpectedException (together with the #handleAssertionErrors option) but the code doesn't do so the test is not failing. This is because the ExpectedException rule catches its own AssertionError issued to signal that the expected exception is not thrown.
The attached commits fix this.

title: Introduce new RANDOM Sorter
Fixed formating in Enclosed Javadoc
body: formated javadoc in Enclosed

title: Example in JavaDoc for Verifier rule is broken
body: The example given on http://kentbeck.github.com/junit/javadoc/4.10/org/junit/rules/Verifier.html has a bit of a weird first line (I'm pretty sure that's not proper Java) and it also uses "MethodRule" as the type for the variable. I assume that should be "TestRule" in new code.

title: GitHub downloads page is not accessible anymore
body:
GitHub has decided to get rid of the downloads page:
https://github.com/blog/1302-goodbye-uploads

It's still accessible but only for about 70 days from now on (and it looks strange):
https://github.com/KentBeck/junit/downloads

What options do we have for hosting our downloads now?

title: Support @Rule for methods works only for TestRule but not for MethodRule
body: The support introduced in https://github.com/KentBeck/junit/issues/83 seems to work now (in JUnit 4.11) only for org.junit.rules.TestRule implementations, but it misses org.junit.rules.MethodRule (un-deprecated again) when looking for methods annotated by @Rule

title: Sorter#NULL seems to be a constant
body:
A trivial fix.

It looks like the designer of the class `Sorter` ment a constant by

`public static Sorter NULL = `

which should be 

`public static final Sorter NULL = `

title: Fix rawtype compiler warnings found when compiling with JDK7
Pull request #499 by skazzyy
body:
Fix issue #499 where Assume cannot be used in tests when Thoeries also
exist in test class.

title: Implement new feature to allow shuffling of Tests.
body:
This adds new methods to Request class shuffled() and shuffledWith() which will
give a Request whose Tests will be shuffled.

This is meant as a do over for what I intended with PR #584. I believe the concerns raised in the other PR should be addressed with this new patch. The new methods shuffled() and shuffledWith() more accurately represent what is intended to happen with the Tests, as I was implementing in the other PR. Also, the shuffledWith() takes a Random which can constructed with a set seed.

Some core classes are modified, but they only add methods and do not modify any other existing code.

title: Fix for issue #499 Assumes in tests run by Theories
body:
Fixes an issue (#499) where Assume cannot be used in a method annotated
by @Test if theories also exist in that test class.

title: @Theory does not support 'expected' for expected exceptions, unlike @Test
Discussing the checkstyle, code coverage and code analysis plugins in new build process.
body:
After #511 we may now discuss addons of Maven plugins which may automate the development process we are doing manually like checking the code style, checking code issues and test coverage.

@avandeursen mentioned his link in #511 which forced me to start this discussion.
http://avandeursen.wordpress.com/2012/12/21/line-coverage-lessons-from-junit

After little searching on google:
+ checkstyle plugins
http://maven.apache.org/plugins/maven-checkstyle-plugin/index.html
+ code analysis plugins FindBug, PMD plugin maven 1x?
+ code coverage plugins JaCoCo, EMMA

EMMA does not integrate with JUnit, and there might be more other plugins in these categories.

How much can we benefit from reports produced by these plugins ?
How can we integrate these reports in CloudBees/Jenkins ?

title: New Javadoc stylesheet.css
body:
I changed the stylesheet.css locally, and got nice looking layout.

To me this way the javadoc is more attractive and has good readability.

http://junit.czweb.org/apidocs/index.html
(same stylesheet.css from Java 7 API spec)

What you think about the javadoc layout. Can we change it like this?
